lg.l: If the world could not go on without water, the constant course
for all people could not go on without rain.

div.p: (i-ḷ). evvakai mēmpāṭṭārkkum nīrai yiṉṟi ulakiyal amaiyātāyiṉ, annīr iṭaiyaṟā toḻukum oḻukkum vāṉai yiṉṟi yamaiyātu, (e - ṟu).

The meaning ... : If [it is true that], without water, the worldly conduct (more lit. "course(s) of the world") of all kinds of eminent people would not go on, [it is equally true that], without rain(/heaven), the uninterruptedly flowing flow of that water, too, would not go on.

poruḷiṉpaṅkaḷai ulakiyal eṉṟār; avai immaikkaṇṇavākaliṉ. iṭaiyaṟātoḻukutal ekkālattumevviṭattu muḷatātal. nīriṉṟamaiyā tulakeṉpatu ellārāṉun teḷiyap paṭutaliṉ atu pōla oḻukkum vāṉiṉ ṟamaiyāmai teḷiyappaṭumeṉpār, ‘nīriṉṟamaiyā tulakeṉiṉ’ eṉṟār. itaṉai nīraiyiṉṟiyamaiyā tulakāyiṉ ettiṟattārkkum maḻaiyaiyiṉṟi yoḻukkam nirampāteṉavuraippārumuḷar.

[The poet] has called [the human goals of] welfare and pleasure "(the course of) the world," because they are things [that are pursued] in this world. Uninterrupted flowing [here means] being present in every time and place. [The poet] has said "If the world could not go on without water" while intending to say(?) that, because the fact that the world would no longer exist without water is clearly apparent to all, the fact that the flow [of that water] would no longer exist without rain(/heaven) is equally (lit. "like that") apparent. There are also those who say that [the meaning is as follows]: If [it is true that] the world could not go on without water, [it is equally true that] the conduct appropriate to each kind of person could not be fulfilled without rain.
ivaimūṉṟu pāṭṭāṉum maḻai aṟam poruḷiṉpaṅkaḷ naṭattaṟ kētuvātal kūṟappaṭṭatu.
Through these three verses, it has been stated that rain is the cause for the continued existence of dharma, welfare, and pleasure.
(i - ḷ.) nīraiyiṉṟi yulakam amaiyātāyiṉ, yāvarkkum maḻaiyai yiṉṟi oḻukkam uṇṭākātu, (e - ṟu).
The meaning ... : If [it is true that] the world would not remain without water, [then] the [good] conduct of everyone would be inexistent without rain.
oḻukkam - viratam. ik̲tu ācāraṅkeṭumeṉṟatu. ivai mūṉṟiṉāṉum nāṉkaṟamuṅ keṭumeṉṟu kūṟiṉār.

"Activities" refer to [religious] vows. This [means] that [religio-moral] conduct would perish. Through these three [verses, Vaḷḷuvar] has said that the four dharmas [i.e. those of the four varṇas] would perish.
